pages.title: About Sarah
pages.content:
Hey, I'm Sarah! üëã

I'm a 28-year-old London-based travel writer who left a corporate marketing job in 2021 to see the world. Best decision I ever made.

Since then, I've visited 43 countries across 5 continents, lived in 4 cities, and filled 6 journals. This blog is where I share the honest, unfiltered version of travel ‚Äî not just the Instagram highlights.

What I Write About

I focus on slow travel, budget adventures, and solo female travel. I believe you don't need a trust fund to see the world ‚Äî just curiosity, courage, and a decent pair of walking shoes.

By the Numbers

43
Countries
5
Continents
200+
Articles
50K+
Readers

Work With Me

I collaborate with tourism boards, travel brands, and hotels on content partnerships, sponsored trips, and social media campaigns. I'm selective ‚Äî I only work with brands I genuinely love and would recommend to friends.

Email: hello@wanderlustchronicles.com
pages.meta_description: Meet Sarah Mitchell ‚Äî London-based travel writer, 43 countries and counting. Honest travel stories and budget tips.

pages.title: Destinations
pages.content:
Guides, stories, and tips from everywhere I've been. Click a destination to explore.

üá™üá∫ Europe

Italy

Amalfi Coast, Tuscany, Rome, Florence. The country that taught me slow travel and good food.

Greece

Santorini sunsets, Athens street food, island hopping through the Cyclades.

Portugal

Lisbon's tiles, Porto's wine, the Algarve's hidden beaches. Europe's best-kept secret.

üåè Asia

Japan

Tokyo's neon chaos, Kyoto's temple gardens, Osaka's street food scene.

Thailand

Bangkok temples, Chiang Mai mountains, islands that look too beautiful to be real.

Vietnam

Ha Long Bay, Hoi An lanterns, Hanoi's old quarter. The most underrated country in Asia.

üåé Americas

Peru

Machu Picchu at sunrise, Lima's ceviche, the Sacred Valley's magic.

Mexico

Oaxaca's mezcal, Tulum's cenotes, Mexico City's incredible food scene.

Canada

Banff's turquoise lakes, Vancouver's mountains-meets-ocean vibe, Montr√©al's poutine.

pages.title: Travel Resources
pages.content:
Everything I use and recommend after 5 years of full-time travel. No fluff, just the stuff that actually works.

Packing Essentials

  • Backpack: Osprey Fairview 40L ‚Äî fits as carry-on, opens like a suitcase
  • Packing cubes: Eagle Creek compression cubes ‚Äî game changer
  • Day bag: Fj√§llr√§ven K√•nken ‚Äî lightweight, waterproof, classic
  • Travel towel: Dock & Bay microfibre ‚Äî dries in 30 minutes

Best Travel Apps

  • Google Maps: Download offline maps before you go
  • Wise: Best exchange rates, no fees, multi-currency card
  • Hostelworld: For budget accommodation worldwide
  • Rome2Rio: How to get from A to B anywhere
  • Google Translate: Camera translation is magic

Budget Tips

  • Travel in shoulder season (April-May, September-October)
  • Cook half your meals ‚Äî hostels with kitchens save fortunes
  • Use Skyscanner's "everywhere" search for cheap flights
  • Consider house-sitting ‚Äî free accommodation worldwide
  • Walk everywhere ‚Äî cheapest and best way to see a city

Camera Gear

  • Camera: Fujifilm X-T4 ‚Äî compact, beautiful colours, weather-sealed
  • Lens: 18-55mm f/2.8-4 ‚Äî covers 90% of travel situations
  • Phone: iPhone 15 Pro ‚Äî honestly rivals the camera for quick shots
  • Tripod: JOBY GorillaPod ‚Äî lightweight, flexible, fits anywhere

Travel Insurance

I use SafetyWing for long-term travel insurance ‚Äî $45/month, covers 180+ countries, no fixed end date. They also cover COVID and adventure activities. After a hospital visit in Thailand cost me ¬£2,000, I never travel without insurance.
pages.excerpt: My tried-and-tested travel gear, apps, and budget tips
pages.meta_description: Recommended travel gear, apps, budget tips, and insurance from 5 years of full-time travel.

articles.title: 48 Hours in Tokyo: The Ultimate First-Timer's Guide
articles.content:
Tokyo hit me like a beautiful, neon-lit freight train. After landing at Narita, I stepped onto the Skyliner and watched Japan unfold through the window ‚Äî rice paddies giving way to suburbs giving way to the most electrifying cityscape I've ever seen.

Day 1: Tradition & Temples

Start at Senso-ji Temple in Asakusa ‚Äî arrive before 8 AM and you'll have the grounds almost to yourself. The smell of incense, the creak of wooden prayer wheels, the ancient red gate ‚Äî it's the perfect antidote to jet lag.

Walk to Ueno Park for a stroll (and free Wi-Fi). Lunch at a standing soba bar ‚Äî 500 yen for the best noodles of your life.

Afternoon: Meiji Shrine in Harajuku, then lose yourself in the fashion chaos of Takeshita Street. End the day in Shinjuku ‚Äî Golden Gai's tiny 6-seat bars are an experience you won't forget.

Day 2: Future & Food

Morning at Tsukiji Outer Market for the freshest sushi breakfast. Visit teamLab Borderless (book tickets weeks in advance). Afternoon in Shibuya ‚Äî cross the world's busiest intersection and feel alive.

For dinner, pick any restaurant with a queue of Japanese salarymen. They know where the good food is.

Budget Tip

Get a 48-hour metro pass (1,600 yen) and a prepaid Suica card. Convenience store food (onigiri, egg sandwiches) is genuinely delicious and costs under ¬£3 for a meal.
articles.excerpt: How to experience the best of Tokyo in just 48 hours ‚Äî temples, ramen, neon, and everything in between.
articles.meta_description: The ultimate first-timer's guide to 48 hours in Tokyo. Temples, food, nightlife, and budget tips.

articles.title: Why Portugal Is the Best-Kept Secret in Europe
articles.content:
I spent 3 weeks in Portugal expecting to like it. I left absolutely in love with it. Here's why this small Atlantic nation deserves more hype than it gets.

It's Ridiculously Affordable

While Paris and Barcelona drain your wallet, Portugal lets you live well for less. A glass of wine in Lisbon: ‚Ç¨2. A full lunch special: ‚Ç¨8. A stunning Airbnb in Porto: ‚Ç¨40/night. I spent less in 3 weeks here than 10 days in Scandinavia.

The Food Is Underrated

Forget what you think you know about Portuguese food. Past√©is de nata (custard tarts) still warm from the oven. Bacalhau cooked 365 different ways. Fresh grilled sardines by the coast. Francesinha in Porto ‚Äî a sandwich that's basically a heart attack between bread, and worth every bite.

The People

The Portuguese are genuinely the warmest people I've met in Europe. Not in a tourist-industry way ‚Äî in a "here, try my grandmother's recipe" way. I was invited into strangers' homes twice in one week.

The Algarve's Hidden Side

Skip the resort beaches. Rent a car and drive to Praia da Marinha, Benagil Cave, or the deserted coves near Aljezur. The coastline is jaw-dropping and ‚Äî outside July and August ‚Äî blissfully uncrowded.

Verdict: Portugal is what Italy was 20 years ago. Go now, before everyone else catches on.
articles.excerpt: Affordable, delicious, and impossibly beautiful ‚Äî Portugal is Europe's most underrated destination.
articles.meta_title: Why Portugal Is Europe's Best Secret ‚Äî Wanderlust Chronicles
articles.meta_description: Why Portugal deserves more hype. Affordable food, stunning coastline, and the warmest people in Europe.

articles.title: How I Travel Full-Time on a Budget of $2,000/Month
articles.content:
The number one question I get asked: "How do you afford this?" The honest answer: I spend less than most people's London rent. Here's the full breakdown.

The Monthly Budget

Accommodation: $700-900 ‚Äî Mix of hostels ($15-25/night), house-sitting (free), and Airbnbs in cheap countries. In Southeast Asia, $500 gets you a month in a private room.

Food: $400-500 ‚Äî I cook 50% of meals. Street food in Asia: $2-3/meal. I splurge on one nice restaurant per week.

Transport: $200-300 ‚Äî Budget airlines, overnight buses, trains. I book 6-8 weeks ahead. Skyscanner's "everywhere" search is my secret weapon.

Insurance: $45 ‚Äî SafetyWing. Non-negotiable.

Everything else: $200-300 ‚Äî SIM cards, activities, coffee (my one real vice), coworking spaces when needed.

How I Earn

Freelance writing (40%), blog income (35%), social media partnerships (25%). It took 2 years to replace my corporate salary. The first year was scary. Now I earn more than I did at my desk job.

The Real Secret

Geographic arbitrage. Earn in pounds, spend in baht. Live in places where your money goes further. I spent 4 months in Chiang Mai for what 6 weeks in London would cost.

Full-time travel isn't about being rich. It's about being strategic with where you live and what you spend on.
articles.excerpt: The full breakdown: how I afford full-time travel on $2,000 per month.
articles.meta_title: How I Travel on $2,000/Month ‚Äî Wanderlust Chronicles
articles.meta_description: Full budget breakdown of full-time travel. Accommodation, food, transport, and how to earn while travelling.

articles.title: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Santorini
articles.content:
Santorini is one of those rare places that actually looks better in person than in photos. But if you want to capture the magic, here are the spots that deliver every time.

  1. Oia Blue Domes ‚Äî The classic shot. Go at sunrise to avoid the crowds (seriously ‚Äî by 10 AM it's shoulder-to-shoulder).
  2. Oia Sunset Point ‚Äî The most famous sunset in Europe. Arrive 2 hours early for a front-row spot at the castle ruins.
  3. Fira to Oia Hiking Trail ‚Äî 10km of caldera views. The section near Imerovigli is the most photogenic.
  4. Skaros Rock ‚Äî A short hike from Imerovigli. Dramatic volcanic rock with 360¬∞ views of the caldera.
  5. Red Beach ‚Äî Surreal red volcanic cliffs against turquoise water. Best photographed from the cliff above.
  6. Amoudi Bay ‚Äî Take the 300 steps down from Oia for fishing boats, tavernas, and cliff-jumping photos.
  7. Santo Wines Winery ‚Äî Vineyards with the caldera as backdrop. The sunset here rivals Oia ‚Äî with better wine.
  8. Pyrgos Village ‚Äî The highest point on the island. Medieval streets, zero tourists, incredible panoramas.
  9. Vlychada Beach ‚Äî Moon-like white cliffs. Feels like another planet. Almost no one goes here.
  10. Megalochori Village ‚Äî Pastel doors, bougainvillea, narrow lanes. The "real" Santorini that tourists miss.

Pro tip: Rent an ATV ($25/day) to reach the hidden spots. And please ‚Äî don't stand on people's rooftops for photos. It's someone's home.
articles.excerpt: From blue domes to secret beaches ‚Äî the 10 best photo spots in Santorini.
articles.meta_title: 10 Instagrammable Spots in Santorini ‚Äî Wanderlust Chronicles
articles.meta_description: The 10 best photo spots in Santorini, including hidden gems most tourists miss.

articles.title: Solo Female Travel: Safety Tips from 5 Years on the Road
articles.content:
In 5 years of solo travel across 43 countries, I've never had a serious safety incident. That's not luck ‚Äî it's preparation. Here's what I've learned.

Before You Go

Research. Read recent blogs and forums about your destination. Know which neighbourhoods to avoid. Learn basic phrases in the local language ‚Äî "no" and "help" at minimum.

Share your itinerary. I send my parents a Google Maps timeline of where I'll be. They can see my location in real-time. Low-tech alternative: daily check-in texts.

On the Ground

Trust your instincts. If something feels wrong, leave. Don't worry about being polite. Your safety matters more than someone's feelings.

Dress for context. I'm not saying cover up everywhere ‚Äî but observing how local women dress helps you blend in and attracts less unwanted attention.

Keep your phone charged. It's your map, your translator, your emergency phone, and your lifeline. Carry a portable battery.

Accommodation

Book places with good reviews from solo female travellers specifically. First night in a new city: always have accommodation pre-booked. Inner-door locks are non-negotiable.

The Truth About Solo Female Travel

The world is overwhelmingly full of good people. I've received more kindness from strangers than I could ever repay. Don't let fear stop you from going ‚Äî let preparation give you the confidence to enjoy every moment.
articles.excerpt: Practical safety advice from 5 years of solo female travel across 43 countries.
articles.meta_title: Solo Female Travel Safety Tips ‚Äî Wanderlust Chronicles
articles.meta_description: 5 years, 43 countries. Practical safety tips for solo female travellers from someone who's been there.

articles.title: Packing Light: Everything I Carry in a 40L Backpack
articles.content:
Five years ago, I travelled with a 65L backpack and a daypack. Now I fit everything into 40 litres. Here's the complete list.

Clothes (10 items)

  • 3 t-shirts (merino wool ‚Äî doesn't smell, dries fast)
  • 1 long-sleeve shirt (doubles as sun protection)
  • 1 pair of jeans
  • 1 pair of travel shorts
  • 1 light dress (works for dinners and temples)
  • 1 packable rain jacket
  • 5 underwear + 3 pairs of socks
  • 1 swimsuit

Tech

  • Laptop (MacBook Air ‚Äî lightweight, all-day battery)
  • Fujifilm X-T4 + 18-55mm lens
  • iPhone + charger
  • Portable battery (20,000mAh)
  • Universal adapter
  • Noise-cancelling earbuds

Toiletries

Solid shampoo bar, solid conditioner, mini deodorant, sunscreen (buy locally ‚Äî always fresher), toothbrush, tiny first aid kit.

The Secret: The One-In-One-Out Rule

If I buy a souvenir, something else leaves the bag. No exceptions. I mail postcards instead of buying trinkets. Memories don't weigh anything.

Total weight: 8.2 kg packed. 7kg carry-on limit? I wear my jeans and jacket on the plane. Works every time.
articles.excerpt: The complete packing list for full-time travel in a single 40L carry-on backpack.
articles.meta_title: Packing Light: My 40L Backpack List ‚Äî Wanderlust Chronicles
articles.meta_description: Everything I carry for full-time travel in a 40L backpack. Complete packing list and tips.
